summary: This is an internal email chain among U.S. Attorneys discussing plea negotiations for Jeffrey Epstein. It reveals concerns about victim notification, a strategic deadline for indictment, and media leaks about the case. The email references a proposed federal conspiracy plea that was rejected.

persons.name: Acosta, Alex
persons.context: The email is addressed to him, and it mentions that he rejected a proposed federal plea agreement for Epstein.

persons.name: Epstein, Jeffrey
persons.context: The subject of the plea negotiations; the email discusses potential charges, a plea deal, and the possibility of his detention.

persons.name: Starr, Ken
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to press coverage about him in the New York media.

persons.name: Junior
persons.context: Received a call from the Palm Beach Police Chief about a media leak regarding Epstein's plea deal.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, was involved in the decision to reject a proposed federal plea agreement for Epstein.

events.title: Proposed Indictment Presentation Deadline
events.description: Strategic deadline to present an indictment against Epstein before the end of September.

events.title: Anticipated Media Article Release
events.description: An article was expected to be released about a meeting and Epstein pleading to a state charge, prompting a call from the Palm Beach Police Chief.

keyFacts: A proposed federal plea agreement for Epstein charging a conspiracy with a two-year cap was discussed but rejected by Alex Acosta.
Prosecutors had a strategic deadline to indict Epstein by presenting the indictment on September 25, 2007.
Prosecutors had not yet consulted with the victims about the plea deal, which was noted as a legal requirement.
There was a media leak about the plea negotiations, leading to a call from the Palm Beach Police Chief to the U.S. Attorney's office.
Prosecutors believed they had a good chance of getting Epstein detained and did not want to promise self-surrender.
